The yield of product is linearly dependent on the BCD: substrate molar ratio, up to a maximum at equimolarity. Key words: aqueous medium; borneol; G-cyclodextrin; inverse phase-transfer catalyst; isobomeol; menthol; oxidation ss-Cyclodextrin (BCD), due to its ability to form inclusion complexes with a variety of organic compounds has aroused much interest, because of increased solubility of the included guest in aqueous systems [ 1 ] . A variety of organic reactions has been attempted in aqueous media, making use of inverse phase-transfer catalysis by BCD, which solubilizes insoluble organic substrates in water, facilitating reactions when present even in catalytic amounts [ 2 ] . Secondary alcohols are converted to carbonyl compounds, when treated with an excess of NaOCI under a two phase system, containing catalytic amounts of a suitable phasetransfer catalyst [ 3 ] . However, this procedure failed, when conversion of a cyclic secondary alcohol like bomeol to camphor was attempted, which however led to a complex mixture of polymeric products [4]. Due to their insolubility in water, little or no reaction occurs, which is also highlighted by the fact that, their reactivity is enhanced by the use of a mixture of CH3CN and CH3COOH, in 3 : 2 ratio [ 5 ] . *Corresponding author. 0304-5102/94/$07.00 1994 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved SSD10304-5102(93) E0314-7 L I 18 R. Ravichandran, S. Divakar /Journal of Molecular Catalysis 88 (1994) L117-L120 However, we have found that secondary alcohols like isoborneol, borneol and menthol can be smoothly converted to their corresponding ketones with solid Ca(OCI)2 in an aqueous medium, using BCD as an inverse phase-transfer catalyst, which can be recovered and reused without any loss (Scheme 1) . The yields of products are unexpectedly affected by BCD: substrate molar ratio. Calcium hypochlorite is a commercially available, inexpensive, solid oxidant which is relatively stable in comparison to NaOCI solutions and hence easy to handle. In a typical experiment, equimolar amounts (2.0 mmol) of .the substrate (isoborneol, Aldrich, USA; borneol and menthol, Pfaltz and Bauer, Germany) and the reagent (Ca(OCl)2), (commercial swimming pool bleach with an available chlorine content of 62.8%) along with BCD (in various molar ratios) was -stirred in 20 ml of water at 50 C for 6 h. The reaction mixture was acidified and extracted with ether, dried and concentrated. The products were analysed by GLC on a HP 5730 A gas chromatography instrument fitted with a Carbowax 2M, 6 ft column maintained at I 10 C with a nitrogen flow rate of 30 ml/ min. The injection port was at 200 C and the FID detector was at 250 C. Clear separation of isoborneol (RT (GC retention timed): 8.85 min), borneol (RT: 10.47 min), camphor (RT: 4.89 min), menthol (RT: 8.10 min) and menthone (RT: 4.05 min) were achieved. The results are shown in Table 1. It can be seen that, the oxidation does not proceed in water alone ( < 1 %) . The problem of substrate insolubility in water can be overcome by using either a suitable co-solvent [ 5 ] or a phase-transfer catalyst [ 3 ] or an inverse phasetransfer catalyst [ 2] , which helps in the transfer of substrate from one phase to the other. Thus, the presence of BCD as an inverse phase-transfer catalyst, increased the yield of the reaction products. No catalytic effect of BCD in the title reaction could be found. However, the yield increased linearly with increase in the BCD: substrate molar ratio. Maximum yield was observed with an equimolar amount of BCD to substrate, comparable to that obtained in the CH3CN:CH3COOH system [5]. The presence of BCD also aided in the total disappearance of byproducts with GC retention times (in min): isoborneol: 2.44, 3.18, 7.04; borneol: 2.42, 2.92, 3.26, 7.03 and menthol: 2.44, 3.09, 9.16, which were observed in CH3CN:CH3COOH system. BCD also showed high selectivity over menthone formation, and totally suppressed the formation of isomenthone, which was observed in the CH3CN : CH3COOH system.
